awd_titl_txt: RUI: Searches for New Physics with the CMS Detector at the LHC
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project by Siena College to carry out fundamental research with the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment at the Large Hadron Collider, at the CERN laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The Siena group participates in the experiment through an association with the Cornell University high-energy physics group. Siena undergraduates contribute to physics analyses that probe some of the most fundamental questions in physics. The group has contributed to a measurement of the differential cross section for production of high momentum top/antitop quark pairs, supported the CMS data preservation efforts with brand new educational tools, restarted an effort to search for baryon-number violating (BNV) decays of the top quark, and engaged local high school teachers and their students to teach them about this exciting work. The group now leads efforts to search for BNV decays of the top quark with Run II data, developing novel approaches along the way. New efforts in data preservation and speculative dark matter searches are also part of this project. Siena will continue this effort primarily to use these data for education, outreach, and training.

The observed matter/antimatter asymmetry in the universe is 8 orders of magnitude larger than can be accommodated by the combination CP violation in the quark sector and baryon-number violating processes allowed in the Standard Model. The most striking consequence of this would be proton decay, but extensive searches for this process have yielded no signal. If BNV is mediated by a boson that operates through a more complicated flavor/generation structure, then it may manifest more strongly in higher generation quarks and leptons. The Siena group will expand the search for BNV decays of the top quark, any observation of which would transform particle physics. The nature of dark matter is one of the most significant outstanding questions in physics and a key missing element of the Standard Model. The Siena group will carry out new speculative dark matter searches in which the CMS detector is used in a direct detection mode, looking for large deposits of energy not associated with a bunch crossing, and in indirect detection mode, searching for standard model particles pointing up from the ground and originating from the decay of dark matter particles gravitationally trapped in the Earth.

Through this project, Siena College students have the opportunity to contribute to physics analyses and to present their work at conferences and carry out their research at major world laboratories. These efforts will focus on both exciting the general public about what humanity is learning about Nature and how the Universe works, but also on encouraging young people to consider careers in STEM fields. The Siena group emphasizes reaching out to women and other traditionally underrepresented groups in physics in local high schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the PI and more than 20 Siena Physics and Applied Physics majors to contribute to analysis efforts with the CMS collaboration, facilitate workshops dedicated to open access CMS datasets, mine the BaBar dataset for signs of new physics, and develop outreach and education tools that have been used by undergraduate students the world over. 

Our group contributed to an effort to search for baryon-number violating (BNV) decays of the top quark, the heaviest known elementary particle. These decays would be a sign of a new instability of matter that could explain why our world is mostly matter with very little antimatter in it. 

We have also initiated the first search for signs of dark matter decays that come from outside of the CMS detector, a first for a collider experiment. We have modeled the backgrounds and find that this is a very low-background search. In the next year, we will be working closely with our collaborators to comb our datasets for signs up upward-traveling muons coming from below CMS.

Our group is very involved in the CMS Data Preservation and Open Access (DPOA) group and has contributed to and facilitated, either in person or remote, at six (6) open data workshops designed to teach theorists and other interested scientists how to use access and analyze these datasets. The efforts of the DPOA group have resulted in more than 50 publications from non-CMS scientists who made use of this open CMS data.

The PI and Siena students have built and maintained an outreach website, Particle Physics Playground,that provides simplified data from particle physics experiments for use in outreach and education. The data come primarily from CMS, BaBar, and CLEO and simplified python code is provided to show how to work with these data. These are used in classrooms at Siena and other places and we have been contacted by students as far as Italy and Brazil who have used the website for student projects. 

Many Siena students are interested in pursuing engineering careers through our Applied Physics program and look for hands-on construction projects. The Siena group has developed our own design, derived from others websites, of Petler-powered cloud chambers, relieving us of the need for dry ice. These have not only proved popular projects for students but useful for outreach efforts to the public and with high schools as well as in the classroom. We are now working to develop an undergraduate lab built around their use. 

The PI contributes to the CMS upgrade efforts as the co-coordinator for a dedicated internship for students from underrepresented identities and underresourced schools so that they can spend a summer contributing to these upgrades. In addition, the PI has been a facilitator at the similarly-oritented PURSUE program. 

Siena students have found these opportunities invaluable and many speak of these experiences as turning points in their career goals. Students supported by this grant have gone on to graduate programs in physics and engineering as well as jobs in physics and data science. There is no substitute for doing cutting-edge research as an undergrad as the success of these students can attest to.
